summary: This document is an email chain from January 2020 among staff at the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York, primarily concerning logistical issues (flight and hotel bookings) for an international trip to Stockholm, Sweden, for an interview related to the Epstein investigation (case 2018R01618). The correspondence reveals ongoing investigative travel and internal coordination frustrations.

persons.name: Darlene Alleyne
persons.role: Legal Assistant, Public Corruption Unit, U.S. Attorney's Office
persons.context: The primary sender/recipient handling travel arrangements for the investigation team; apologizes for booking errors and provides revised itineraries.

persons.name: Alex
persons.context: Primary requester of travel approvals and bookings; is frustrated with non-refundable flight bookings and coordination issues for trips related to the Epstein investigation.

persons.name: Alison
persons.context: Colleague traveling on the same trip; mentioned as being on a specific flight that Alex did not want to take.

persons.name: Edward Tyrrell
persons.role: Supervisor / Approving Official (likely AUSA or Office Manager)
persons.context: The official who approves travel requests for the Epstein investigation team.

persons.name: James Bullock
persons.role: Colleague / Staff (likely in Budget or Admin)
persons.context: Mentioned as being informed about pending hotel scheduling for the travel.

persons.name: Cynthia Perez
persons.context: Cc'd on an internal travel approval email.

persons.name: Michele Duncan
persons.context: Cc'd on multiple travel approval requests; appears to be part of the administrative or legal team.

persons.name: Maurene
persons.context: Frequently mentioned as a potential traveler for victim interviews in Los Angeles and West Palm Beach as part of the Epstein investigation.

connections.description: Colleagues within the U.S. Attorney's Office; Alex requests travel bookings from Alleyne, who is the legal assistant handling logistics.
Alex submits travel approval requests to Tyrrell, who is the approving official for investigative travel.
Colleagues and co-travelers on multiple trips for the Epstein investigation, including the planned Stockholm trip.
Colleagues and co-travelers for victim interviews in West Palm Beach and Los Angeles as part of the Epstein investigation.
Colleagues coordinating travel logistics; Alleyne informed Bullock about pending hotel scheduling.

events.title: Planned Travel to Stockholm for Interview
events.description: The investigative team (Alex, Alison) plans to travel from New York (JFK) to Stockholm, Sweden, via Paris, to conduct an interview related to the Epstein investigation.

events.title: Travel to Los Angeles for Interview
events.description: The team requested permission to travel to Los Angeles for an interview (or interviews) related to the Epstein investigation.

events.title: Interview in West Palm Beach
events.description: Alex and Maurene planned to travel to West Palm Beach, Florida, for an interview related to the Epstein investigation, requesting a conference room.

events.title: Victim Interview in Los Angeles
events.description: The team (Alex, Alison, and/or Maurene) requested permission to travel to Los Angeles for a victim interview, with plans to reserve a conference room.

keyFacts: The document is a series of internal emails from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York regarding travel for the Epstein investigation (case 2018R01618).
The primary purpose of the travel detailed in the most recent emails (Jan 2020) is to conduct an interview near Stockholm, Sweden, indicating the international scope of the investigation.
The correspondence reveals ongoing investigative activity throughout 2019, with multiple trips to Los Angeles and West Palm Beach for victim interviews and meetings.
The emails show internal friction over travel logistics, specifically regarding the booking of refundable vs. non-refundable international flights.
The case is formally referenced as 'United States v. Epstein, 2018R01618, an investigation relating to enticement of minors for sexual activity.'
